docs.lead_paragraph: Parliament agreed to a national referendum, probably in January, on legalizing abortion. If approved, abortion would be legal to the 10th week of pregnancy. Portugal has one of the most restrictive abortion laws in Europe, with the procedure allowed only in cases of rape, fetal malformation or if a woman’s health is at risk. In Europe, only Poland and Ireland have similarly restrictive rules; Malta forbids abortion altogether.

headline.main: Portugal: Legal Abortion to Be Put to the Voters
headline.print_headline: PORTUGAL: LEGAL ABORTION TO BE PUT TO THE VOTERS

docs.lead_paragraph: Gaining even a small amount of weight between pregnancies significantly increases the risk of a poor pregnancy outcome, according to a new study.

headline.main: Having a Baby: Risk Seen in Weight Gain Between Pregnancies
headline.print_headline: Risk Seen in Weight Gain Between Pregnancies

docs.snippet: Gaining even a small amount of weight between pregnancies significantly increases the risk of a poor pregnancy outcome, according to a new study.

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman who gains even a small amount of weight between pregnancies significantly increases her risk of a poor pregnancy outcome, according to a new study. The study, which appears in the September 30 issue of The Lancet, used the records of more than 150,000 Swedish women who had first and second consecutive births from 1992 through 2001. The researchers calculated body mass index, or B.M.I., at the beginning of the first pregnancy and again at the start of the second.

headline.main: Risk Seen in Weight Gain Between Pregnancies

docs.abstract: Eduardo Villamor, Harvard School of Public Health assistant professor, leads study that finds increased risk of pregnancy complications if mother gained weight between pregnancies; research is published in journal Lancet; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Terrazas have become a civic fixture in Madrid.

headline.main: A Night Out on the Terraza in Madrid
headline.print_headline: A Night Out on the Terraza

docs.snippet: Terrazas have become a civic fixture in Madrid.

docs.lead_paragraph: TERRAZAS, or terraces, are not the slice of real estate hanging off an apartment building in Madrid. The word refers, reverentially, to an outdoor cafe culture that arguably means more to Madrid than sidewalk dining does in Paris or New York. Each year brings more and more. And, in the latest sign that terrazas have become a civic fixture, they are now staying open long past summer, after the sweaters and coats appear. Maybe it was inevitable. Terrazas encapsulate Madrid's personality perfectly: nocturnal, communal and endlessly outgoing. The arrival of new terrazas is greeted with no less urgency than the celebrity magazine Hola!'s coverage of Princess Letizia's second royal pregnancy. They are written about, parsed and blogged with an obsession usually reserved for soccer teams.

headline.main: A Night Out on the Terraza

docs.snippet: Terrazas have become a civic fixture in Madrid.
